newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: FOCUS-UBS has 1996 loss on one-time charge.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-UBS has 1996 loss on one-time charge.

text.p: Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS), the country's biggest bank, reported an expected 1996 group net loss of 348 million francs ($235.7 million) on Friday as a result of big one-off provisions for bad domestic loans in Switzerland.

UBS was the first of Switzerland's three global banks to report. All three are due to post losses due to one-time charges aimed at staunching the flow of profits into credit risks caused by six years of Swiss economic stagnation.
Chief executive Mathis Cabiallavetta said the bank now had its provision problems under control and expected a positive year.
"It was a good start in the first two months," he said.

Excluding the special provision and a restructuring charge of 120 million Swiss francs, "group profit would have been in the region of 1.8 billion francs, seven percent more than in 1995", a UBS statement said.

Cabiallavetta said ordinary provisions could now be kept down to between 400 million and 600 million Swiss francs a year, freeing up income for profits that had been going to cover risky domestic loans.
Analysts said they saw no major surprises in the numbers and no reason to revise recommendations, most of which were "hold" or "neutral".
UBS bearer shares were down slightly in a generally weakish market, trading six francs lower at 1,290 Swiss francs in late afternoon.
Rival bank Credit Suisse Group will report on its 1996 results on March 5 and Swiss Bank Corp on March 12.
UBS said it would maintain an unchanged dividend on 1996 results of 32 Swiss francs per bearer share and 6.40 francs per registered share.
"UBS reported a good operating result for 1996. Cash flow was increased by 21 percent to 4,312 million Swiss francs," the bank said in a statement before Cabiallavetta's news conference.
It said return on equity (ROE), the benchmark it uses for measuring gains in profitability, was to increase to around 12 percent in the near future.
"Provided market conditions remain reasonably favourable, we anticipate a rapid increase in our return on equity to around 12 percent," Cabiallavetta said.
He said this was in line with a UBS strategic objective of achieving an ROE of six to eight percent above the risk-free interest rate.
UBS's ROE was 7.5 percent in 1995 and would have been the same again last year if not for the extraordinary charge, which pushed the ratio down to minus 1.5 percent.
One key cost factor was performance bonuses in the competitive world of investment banking, where keeping and hiring experts forces many banks to offer generous packages.
UBS said its personnel costs rose 17 percent in 1996 to 4,857 million Swiss francs due in large part to performance bonuses for a lucrative investment banking year.
Cabiallavetta said UBS would now focus on expanding its asset management business and could not rule out an acquisition in major markets such as the United States.

He said UBS already held an excellent position in this business, particularly in Switzerland, and wanted to use it as a platform to aggressively build up its capabilities abroad. ($ = 1.476 Swiss Francs)
